awd_titl_txt: ICE-T: RI: A Knowledge-Defined Platform for Real-Time Management of Transmissions and Computations at Network Edge
awd_abstract_narration:
Due to the highly dynamic nature of the communications and computations in 5th Generation (5G) cellular communications systems, new services will require real-time management to achieve extremely low latencies in communication and computation. To advance the state of the art, this project explores resource management algorithms that borrow ideas from the use of statistical learning, estimation, and data-driven techniques from high frequency financial trading systems.

The project will design and prototype a platform based on low-cost programmable switches that will allow researchers to experiment with novel statistical learning-based algorithmic solutions for real-time management of edge networks. The platform will have two main research objectives: 1) to explore learning based solutions for real time management of virtual paths and virtual switches; and 2) to investigate real-time management of core 5G computation and network resources, and to orchestrate edge computing processing at the network edge. By leveraging learning theory, the  project will define new abstractions and interfaces that will allow network operators to coordinate computation and traffic allocation decisions at the network edge. This project will develop novel approaches towards understanding the development of algorithmic aspects of prediction of network parameters and computational needs. This project will initiate a new research collaboration between investigators at Saint Louis University and the University of Padova, Italy.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In this US-EU Internet Core & Edge Technologies (ICE-T) project, we proposed to design and prototype novel statistical learning-based algorithmic solutions for real-time management of edge networks tailored to delay-sensitive applications. Our solutions were targeted towards two main research objectives. The first objective was to explore learning-based solutions for real-time management of virtual paths and virtual switches, while the second objective was to design and implement real-time algorithms for the orchestration of computation and network resources at network edge.

To accomplish those goals, we prototype solutions that considered both space and time analytics. In particular, our hypothesis was to learn from geospatial network patterns and history-based analytics using network traces, e.g., generated by widely used traffic engineering and routing algorithms, such as Equal-Cost Multi-Path (ECMP) and Open-Shortest Path First (OSPF). By leveraging learning theory and lessons learned from the high-frequency financial trading world, where the PI was working before joining academia, we defined new abstractions and interfaces that would allow network operators to coordinate computation and traffic allocation decisions at the network edge.

As outcome of our research, we published a set of traffic engineering algorithms that use deep reinforcement learning. In particular, we modeled the problem of minimizing both bandwidth consumption and the expected packet latency of an edge network flow using Markov processes. By doing so, we learned the interactions between each flow and other flows to minimize both bandwidth usage and expected packet latency. We also explored ways to model network traffic using graph theory and applied techniques such as dynamic programming to find the optimal flow of data packets.

Another outcome of our research has been the development of forecasting methodologies for managing edge networks. Building on our initial work on real-time latency forecasting, we explored methodologies to optimize bandwidth availability and computation harvesting in the offloading process. Specifically, we focused on modeling and solving edge resource engineering problems by comparing several non-linear (latency) forecast approaches and proposing real-time path latencies, bandwidth, and energy consumption estimations at the edge.
